Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Expectation2: Fix bugs and troubleshoot issues reported by users or QA
Situation2: Several users report intermittent errors that disrupt normal usage
Story:
My phone buzzes with a message from Mom: “Hope you’re having a good weekend! Call us when you can.” I glance at the clock—Sunday afternoon already. I haven’t called home in over a week, and guilt prickles at me. I know how much it means to my parents to hear my voice, to know I’m okay, to feel connected even if it’s just for a few minutes. I start typing a quick reply, promising to call soon.

But my laptop pings with another notification—another bug report. The app is throwing intermittent errors, and users are frustrated. My team lead has already messaged twice, asking if I can jump on a call to troubleshoot. I feel the pressure mounting; I know how important it is to fix these issues quickly, to keep our users happy and the project on track.

I stare at my phone, then at my laptop, torn between the warmth of my family and the urgency of my work. My heart aches with the weight of both expectations, and I wonder how I can possibly be the daughter my parents need and the developer my team relies on—all at the same time.
